address.streetAddress: 235 Queens Quay W at Lower Simcoe St.

description: Harbourfront Centre, on Toronto's waterfront, is an innovative not-for-profit cultural organization that creates events and activities of excellence that enliven, educate and entertain a diverse public.

reviews.title: Poor service and dated rooms.
text: Very dated hotel which did not feel clean. Long strands of hair in the bathroom sink upon arrival.  Very small bathroom with tub shower and plastic curtain.
Nice view of the lake and fairly spacious room for a downtown city hotel. Very nice restaurant and bar on top floor with talented bar tenders.

But housekeeping did not service our room after our third night despite 2 phone calls to the front desk and multiple texts on the Bonvoy app.  We finally called a third time to ask them to at least bring us clean towels.
Very poor service for a loyal Marriott customer.  Won’t be back despite frequent travel to Toronto.  I would go to the bar again on the top floor but not stay at the hotel.

reviews.title: Made to feel like trash
text: Attended the Toronto International Festival of Authors.  Total cost of a single ticket was $39.99 plus taxes came to $45.19 total.  The tickets did not get sent to my email.  Phoned twice for it and waited 1/2 hour in total and on arrival had to go to customer service to get it printed.  So I missed the only speaking event I wanted to attend.  Did not realize the book signing event, though listed as a free event, required registration.  It was of course full.  So waited in a "rush line" (no guarantee of entrance) for over an hour which security dispersed.   Only to see the author being hurried away down a hallway without even a glance at his waiting fans (only about 20 of us).  A friendly hello wave and/or a few words would have made all the difference in the world.  Security was utterly overbearing what did they think we were going to do to this author?  Nothing, what a complete waste of time and money and we all were left feeling really disappointed, sad and I personally felt at the end of the day, badly treated.  Thanks to the Internatinal Festival of Authors, for wasting my valuable time and hard- earned dollars and making me feel like trash.

reviews.title: Good neighborhood
text: One of the good neighborhoods in Toronto. As the name suggests, the access to lake is provided. Great location for watching both the city skyline and the lake.

reviews.title: A shadow of its former self.
text: A once bustling place, there are only a handful of businesses trading here, which is a pity as it’s in a great place on the waterfront. Even some of the bars had started trading for the winter, even though when we were there in early October the waterfront area was busy. Disappointing.

reviews.title: Good for a Stroll
text: Walk from the Ferry terminal  along the harbour front, very relaxing with some good views across to the Islands

reviews.title: An ideal location
text: ideal location to shoot the sunset. This area gives you an awesome sensation of peace. Good and clean seating areas, long path along the seashore. surrounded by numerous food stands so you may satisfy your hunger while travelling. facilitated by a broad runway at Billy Bishop Airport and a water taxi.

reviews.title: Very nice environment
text: Very nice location along the waterfront. Often it hosts events and lives music in a fantastic environment.

reviews.title: Great walk
text: Lovely area to walk and see the water. Good places to eat and site as well. There is however no walk to distillery area along harbor as heads up.

reviews.title: great views
text: This is a great spot just to walk around and unwind. it's in the Core of downtown and has coffee shops and restaurants.

reviews.title: Green space and water
text: During pandemic things have changed at Harbourfront Centre, where families can normally enjoy public art and activities like canoeing or skating year round. We’ve ridden bikes and picked up food at Loblaws supermarket on Queens Quay before (where cash payment for car-parking is an option). Instead, a shop or two was open along Harbourfront, and the Centre generally remained closed, except its public washrooms on SW exterior. We bought takeout lunch across Queens Quay and could eat on the benches, along with churros from nearby food trucks. Kids can get photos taken above the washroom level, where a colourful outdoor mural is painted. Bicyclists and tourists travelling by TTC streetcars from Union Subway station could relax on the green lawn and patio, overlooking the boardwalk and water. Ferries were running nearby from Westin to Toronto /Centre Island, and people wore masks to stay socially distanced and safe. I plan to return by mid October when leaves are turning colour to catch the scenery of Toronto’s island.

reviews.title: Good to explore
text: We visited the Harbourfront on a Monday afternoon in beautiful sunshine, although it was busy it still manages to be tranquil and a really good place for a walk.

reviews.title: Very interesting
text: I really enjoyed this afternoon out.  It was actually pretty cool I had never been because of people saying Lake Ontario stinks lol. But it was very alive and saw the taxi boats I felt like a tourist.  Overall please check it out Thursday’s they have dancing at the pier this summer.  Very inclusive even people who didn’t dance danced no judgment I loved it.

reviews.title: Very lively. Lots going on.
text: I visited during the Caribbean carnival weekend and this area was buzzing! There was a silent disco ( people dancing to music only they could hear), paddle boats for kids, lots of market stalls selling clothes, jewellery and nic-knacks, live music and lots of street food. Very noisy and very crowded. Good positive energy of people enjoying themselves.

reviews.title: Unplanned Visit
text: Had some time before my ferry ride and Harbourfront Centre was suggested to visit. So I walked over and discovered they have a current exhibit on Broken Relationships. It turned out to be really touching. (ok and a little comical at times) It’s a short, walk through exhibit. So don’t expect to be there too long. Not sure what else goes on at the location, (I had to get back to my ferry) but I was glad to at least feel some a/c, use the restroom and experience something unique and heartfelt. Even if brief....

reviews.title: A fun place to visit
text: Dancing on the Pier every Thursday night through August 29, 2019.  A cruise on the lake is another activity to enjoy. lots of fine restaurants at the  Harbourfront center

reviews.title: lovely place
text: love to go there just to feel the peace of water, lovely places to eat and free concerts, stroll around, exhibitions, bicycle and walks!

reviews.title: Great for a Relaxing Day
text: - Nice, clean, and good for a relaxing day
- Eat and enjoy the lake's view, and even better if you take one of the harbourfront boat tours

reviews.title: Fun place to have fun and relax.
text: Visiting the Toronto Island is a great way to spend your day. Whether it is just having a picnic or renting a bike etc. A great place for all ages.

reviews.title: Walk on the boardwalk
text: Nice walk alone lake Ontario, lots of restaurants and shops along the way. U can engage in some sport activity, boating...

reviews.title: Wonderful place.
text: The best beach .Strolling along the lakeside, taking a cool breeze and enjoying the moment with my wife was the most thing i needed in this world and Harbourfront Centre was just the exert place i wanted to be.

reviews.title: STOP FOR A BREATH
text: Wonderful picturesque area of the grand city of Toronto. Very pleasant to stroll around and chill for a while. My wife and I enjoyed the experience.

reviews.title: Lovely area
text: This is a relaxing area to walk or just sit and have a coffee. Lots of eateries. Very clean along the harbourfront and pedestrian friendly.

reviews.title: Disappointing Experience
text: Having lived in Toronto in 1986, I was looking forard to re-tracing my steps from back then, especially seeing the harbour front again. I remember it as being beautiful and very family-oriented. In the ensuing 33 years, it's been butchered by having copious amounts of land fill crowded by wall to wall skyscrapers. There was traffic and noise everywhere and very lttle views of the lake, Shame on you, Toronto City Council for ont valuing the heritage and beauty of your city!

reviews.title: Great place
text: Seamlessly blends with the city and creates area filled with happening and lively events. Worth visiting.

reviews.title: Cultural experience
text: Attended several cultural events. food amazing, great options outside of cultural related foods. Great entertainment. Enjoyed the boardwalk. and all the places to sit and be entertained

reviews.title: Stunning area to relax,have dinner or lunch
text: We visited here a few times during our trip, markets, activities, places to eat and drink, a must see area with stunning views

reviews.title: parking costs an arm and a leg, but do go see the museum of broken relationships
text: I loved the Museum of Broken relationships. It was interesting and well curated. It was a good thing that it was free b/c parking was impossible to find and it cost $25. for just a few hours. It was nice to see crafts people at work in the center, but the gift shop was waaaaay overpriced.

reviews.title: The area
text: This area is a great place to go hang out with lots of things to see and do. Walk around take it in and enjoy.

reviews.title: Love the Harbourfront
text: Some many activities going on! so much to see and do, they cater to everyone all ages, love all the music events, dancing on the pier, the shopping & restaurants a beautiful place to visit, very clean ....I keep going back!!

reviews.title: Lots of energy here
text: It's lovely to stroll around this area on a nice day. There's often a concert or something interesting happening. I was fascinated to watch numerous speed boats dropping people off all along the waterfront, but as a tourist, I was disappointed that there weren't more shops in the area.

reviews.title: Relaxing, fun, good food and friendly atmosphere
text: We live in Toronto but we don't come too often because of our busy schedules. It's always excited to come here and spend the entire evening, specially for the summer time. It always has different events to feature multicultural city. Due to the COVID-19, many facilities are still closed, but we still find things to do here. We had a nice dinner at Amsterdam restaurant. After the dinner, we walked on the boardwalk and enjoyed the breeze, watching the street artists performances. We feel like a staycation without spending too much money. We finished the night with the Beveartails pastry and ice cream 🍦😋 (must try dessert) . It made a perfect ending for us. Totally recommend for couples, families and who enjoy the night life. If you're on a budget, it's perfectly fine to bring your food and have a picnic here. All you need is a peaceful mind enjoy your surroundings.  Have a happy summer to everyone 😊! Stay healthy and keep social distancing!

reviews.title: Great for summer
text: great for any summer trip just comfortable great restaurants and relaxation, you both in and away from the city.

reviews.title: A splendid place for a walk
text: The waterfront area in Toronto has been thoughtfully developed and perfect for strolling. Downtown Toronto is a highly walkable place, and there are lots of access points to get there via the on foot via the PATH system, GO Transit, regular transit. And there are lots of restaurants and cafes when you need some sustenance. The views across the lake and towards town are amazing, and the air was wonderful on our visit.

reviews.title: Nice area for a stroll
text: Very quit on weekdays, but nice for a stroll after lunch. Pleasant for a picnic, enjoying the lake view.

reviews.title: a long walk for not much
text: there is not much here unless you are going to n event and the next street crossing is at Spadina which is a hike up the road.

reviews.title: Lovely Walk in Downtown
text: Walking on the Harbourfront on a crisp, cold day is highly recommended when in the city.
I recommend walking from the CN Tower up to Distillery district, a nice walk overall.

reviews.title: Great view
text: Went to see a concert there and no matter where you sat you had a great view.  There were some good places to eat around here and it looked like everyone was having a great time skating outside of it

reviews.title: A cold windy walk
text: Habourfront is the portion of land on the edge of shores of Lake Ontario bordering downtown Toronto about 5 mins walk from my apartment. The temperature was about 3 degrees but very windy which made it feel like -4 degrees.
Came across a skating rink and parked boats. Some noisy 6 year old school children were on excursion. Could see the planes landing and taking off from the airport on the island across the lake.
Apart from the skating rink not much appears to happen during winter. I came across a stage which suggest lots of shows and events during warmer months

reviews.title: Beautiful Harbour
text: Food Festival was on when I went there. Plenty of food stalls & live entertainments. Nice photo spots toward harbour or the city skyline. Not to miss CN Tower in the background.

reviews.title: Relaxing Experience
text: One can get a relaxing experience while strolling at the harbourfront center. Plenty of eateries and gift shops around. Nice unique views of the city as well. Would certainly recommend visiting same, especially in the evenings.
